poem:
**Dictator's Lunch**

In Fulham's brasserie, opulent and grand,  
Claypot chicken commands the room like an edict,  
While barley fields bow in submission.  
Walls echo verdicts of satisfied cheer,  
A meal both meticulous and martial.  
Here, among forkfuls and grins, power steams—  
Polished cutlery, gleaming in the afterglow of indulgence.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Brasserie Constance, London SW6: ‘A souped-up corporate box with meticulous food’ – restaurant review | Grace Dent on restaurants Over a lunch at Brasserie Constance in Fulham, west London, eating my main course claypot chicken with barley while surrounded by smiling diners at other tables, I got a glimpse of how it must feel to be Kim Jong-un. My journey to Fulham Pier had been odd enough, but now I was in my Great Dictator". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Brasserie Constance, London SW6: ‘A souped-up corporate box with meticulous food’ – restaurant review | Grace Dent on restaurants Over a lunch at Brasserie Constance in Fulham, west London, eating my main course claypot chicken with barley while surrounded by smiling diners at other tables, I got a glimpse of how it must feel to be Kim Jong-un. My journey to Fulham Pier had been odd enough, but now I was in my Great Dictator
